item.title: Install R
item.description:
Scope

In this section, we provide information and advice to install R for the purpose of developing a Bioconductor package.

This section does not seek to provide a comprehensive workflow through the installation of R, as the details will depend on your individual operating system and configuration. Instead, this section includes links to key resources and sources of information.

Which version of R?

The Bioconductor developer guidelines state:

Package authors should develop against the version of R that will be available to users when the Bioconductor devel branch becomes the Bioconductor release branch.

In addition:

This means that, from mid-October through mid-April, Bioconductor developers should be developing against R-devel. From mid-April to mid-October, developers should use R-release (actually, the R snapshot from the R-x-y-branch) for Bioconductor development.

R Sources or R binaries?

R binaries

The CRAN website states:

Windows and Mac users most likely want to download the precompiled binaries listed in the upper box, not the source code. The sources have to be compiled before you can use them.

The main advantage of precompiled R binaries is that they distribute code that can be immediately installed and executed. It is generally the fastest solution to get you started with your own work. However, each binaries is compiled for a specific operating system. To establish a working R installation on your computer, you must find binaries that match your operating system.

R binaries - including both R-release and R-devel - can be obtained from CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/. The navigation panel on the left includes a link ‘R Binaries’.

R sources

The main advantage of R sources is that they distribute the human readable version of the application, which users can then compile on their own system with the right set of tools to yield an installation adapted to their system configuration and libraries. This often pays off when installing R packages that need to be compiled from source themselves. However, installing compilers, keeping them up to date, and compiling sources can be a challenge, even for experienced developers. As the CRAN website states:

If you do not know what this means, you probably do not want to do it!

R sources - including both R-release and R-devel - can be obtained from CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/ The navigation panel on the left includes a link ‘R Sources’.

Alternative installations

  • Homebrew: https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/r
  • Anaconda: https://anaconda.org/r/r

item.title: Install helper packages
item.description:
Overview

This section introduces R packages that were developed to facilitate the development of other R packages.

Install BiocManager

install.packages("BiocManager")

Install usethis

BiocManager::install("usethis")

item.title: Initialize an R package skeleton
item.description:
Create a new package skeleton

From the usethis::create_tidy_package documentation.

Creates a new package, immediately applies as many of the tidyverse conventions as possible, issues a few reminders, and activates the new package.

usethis::create_tidy_package("~/biocpkg")

item.title: Set up GitHub Actions
item.description:
Overview

This section introduces a workflow to set up continuous integration for a working R package.

Open a new git branch

Note: an earlier section will explain how to protect the master branch.

At this point, the master branch of your GitHub repository should be protected. As always, we will work on a branch and merge to the master branch when the continuous integration feature is ready.

git checkout -b ci

Load usethis

library(usethis)

Create a README file

Note: this should be moved to an earlier section, as it is not part of the continuous integration setup per se.

If you haven’t already, use use_readme_md() to create a README.md.

use_readme_md()

Set up the template ‘R CMD check’ action

use_github_action_check_full()

As per documentation:

This action installs the last 5 minor R versions and runs R CMD check via the R BiocStyle::CRANpkg("rcmdcheck") package on the three major OSs (linux, macOS and Windows).

Upon completion, use_github_action_check_full() generates Markdown content that displays a badge indicating the status of the GitHub Action. This content is both copied to your clipboard, and printed in the console. It should look like:

  <!-- badges: start -->
  [![R build status](https://github.com/user/repo/workflows/R-CMD-check/badge.svg)](https://github.com/user/repo/actions)
  <!-- badges: end -->

Paste this content in the badges: section of your README.md file.

Edit the GitHub Action configuration

First, remove the restriction on branches for the push event. This will trigger the action on every push to any branch.

on:
  push:
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - master

Next, keep only the latest ubuntu version, mainly to reduce the number of configurations run as separate jobs. For instance, this would look something like the following (update to the relevant version):

    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        config:
          - {os: macOS-latest,   r: 'devel'}
          - {os: macOS-latest,   r: '4.0'}
          - {os: windows-latest, r: '4.0'}
          - {os: ubuntu-16.04,   r: '4.0', rspm: "https://packagemanager.rstudio.com/cran/__linux__/xenial/latest"}

When working with a Bioconductor package, BiocManager should be installed during the Query dependencies step. This allows BiocManager::repositories() to be called to add Bioconductor package repositories to be added to the global session options. In turn, this allows remotes::dev_package_deps() to query all repositories when identifying dependencies, as it uses the default argument value repos = getOption("repos").

- name: Query dependencies
  run: |
    install.packages(c('remotes', 'BiocManager'))
    options(repos = c(getOption("repos"), BiocManager::repositories()))
    saveRDS(remotes::dev_package_deps(dependencies = TRUE), "depends.Rds", version = 2)
  shell: Rscript {0}

Again, when working with a Bioconductor package, we add Bioconductor package repositories to the global session options during the Install dependencies step. Similarly, the remotes::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE) uses the default argument value repos = getOption("repos").

In this step, you may also add any dependency that is not explicitly declared in the DESCRIPTION file of your package, or installed as an indirect dependency, as well as any esoteric development version of your dependencies.

- name: Install dependencies
  run: |
    options(repos = c(getOption("repos"), BiocManager::repositories()))
    remotes::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE)
    remotes::install_cran("rcmdcheck")
  shell: Rscript {0}
